question_text: Do you use a centralized identity provider IdP for authenticating users to internal business systems?
Are all new user accounts created in the centralized IdP rather than as local application accounts?
Are business critical applications integrated with the centralized IdP for user authentication?
Are there any applications that still use standalone or local user accounts instead of the IdP?
Is there a documented standard that all new applications must use the centralized IdP for user authentication?
Are authentication protocols such as SAML OIDC or OAuth used between applications and the IdP?
Are service accounts and application accounts authenticated through secure mechanisms controlled by the IdP?
Is access to the IdP administrative console restricted to a limited set of authorized administrators?
Are changes to IdP authentication configuration subject to change management and approval?
Are administrative actions on the IdP such as policy changes and user overrides logged and retained?
Do you periodically review which systems are integrated with the centralized IdP?
Does the IdP support strong session management features such as single sign out and token revocation?
Are user identities in the IdP synchronized from authoritative HR or identity sources?
Are stale or unused accounts in the IdP identified and removed or disabled in a timely manner?
Do you use separate IdP tenants or partitions for production and non production environments?
Is Multi Factor Authentication MFA enforced for user access to critical internal systems?
Is MFA required for remote access such as VPN virtual desktop or remote gateways?
Is MFA enforced for privileged and administrative user accounts?
Are there user groups or applications that are explicitly exempted from MFA?
Are MFA exemptions subject to documented approval and periodic review?
Are MFA methods based on strong authenticators such as app based OTP hardware tokens or FIDO security keys?
Do you restrict or avoid the use of weaker MFA methods such as SMS one time codes?
Are MFA settings managed centrally through the IdP or access management platform?
Are users notified when a new MFA device or authenticator is registered for their account?
Are MFA challenges logged including both successful and failed attempts?
Are MFA failures monitored for signs of brute force or credential stuffing attacks?
Do you require MFA for user self service password reset or account recovery processes?
Are time based one time passwords synchronized and protected from replay as part of MFA?
Are MFA requirements clearly defined in security policy and communicated to all relevant users?
Are MFA configurations periodically reviewed to ensure coverage of all critical applications and user groups?
Do you enforce a documented password policy for all user accounts?
Does the password policy define minimum length and complexity requirements?
Are default passwords changed before accounts or systems are put into production use?
Are users prevented from reusing a defined number of previous passwords?
Are passwords for privileged accounts subject to stricter rules than standard user passwords?
Are shared or generic user IDs discouraged or tightly controlled through approvals and monitoring?
Are system and application passwords stored using secure hashing and salting techniques?
Are passwords for administrative or service accounts stored in secure vaults or password managers?
Are temporary or one time passwords expired or changed on first use?
Do you provide secure password reset mechanisms that verify user identity before allowing reset?
Are password reset requests logged and periodically reviewed for unusual activity?
Are users educated on good password practices and phishing risks as part of security awareness?
Do technical controls prevent the use of commonly compromised or dictionary passwords?
Are password policies applied consistently across on premises and cloud based systems?
Do you configure maximum password age and rotation requirements based on risk?
Are passwords for third party and customer user accounts subject to equivalent or stronger policies than internal users?
Are administrative passwords changed promptly when an administrator leaves or changes role?
Do you regularly review password policy settings in directory services and cloud platforms?
Are password changes required after suspected compromise or major security incidents?
Are privileged password activities such as retrieval from vaults audited and monitored?
Do you use Single Sign On SSO for users to access multiple enterprise applications?
Are SSO sessions initiated only after successful strong primary authentication?
Are SSO trust relationships configured only with approved and validated identity providers?
Are SSO tokens or assertions protected against replay and tampering?
Do SSO sessions have defined timeouts and reauthentication requirements for sensitive actions?
Are SSO configurations and metadata changes limited to authorized administrators only?
Are SSO related events such as login failures and assertion validation errors logged and monitored?
Are SSO integrations periodically reviewed to remove unused or high risk connections?
Are user identities and attributes passed in SSO assertions limited to what is necessary for the target application?
Are SSO logout or single sign out functions implemented to terminate sessions across applications where feasible?
Do you use biometric authentication methods such as fingerprint or facial recognition for user access?
Are biometric templates stored securely and protected from unauthorized access or disclosure?
Do you provide non biometric alternative authentication methods for users who cannot or do not consent to biometrics?
Are biometric authentication systems subject to periodic security and privacy risk assessments?
Are biometric authentication logs retained and protected similar to other authentication logs?
Do you enforce automatic account lockout after a defined number of failed login attempts?
Is the account lockout threshold based on risk and type of account for example privileged vs standard users?
Do locked accounts automatically unlock only after a secure process or defined time period?
Are repeated lockouts monitored as indicators of brute force or credential stuffing attacks?
Do you enforce idle session timeouts for interactive user sessions?
Are session timeouts shorter for higher risk applications or privileged sessions?
Are users automatically logged out after a defined period of inactivity on web portals and remote sessions?
Do you prevent multiple concurrent interactive sessions for the same user where not justified by business need?
Are suspicious session patterns such as impossible travel or unusual locations detected and alerted?
Do you have documented procedures for unlocking user accounts and verifying identity before unlock?
Do you use risk based or adaptive authentication checks such as device reputation location or behavior?
Are higher risk authentication attempts challenged with stronger mechanisms such as MFA step up?
Do you evaluate device characteristics such as managed status or compliance posture during authentication?
Do you restrict authentication from high risk locations or anonymizing services unless explicitly approved?
Do you restrict authentication from high risk locations or anonymizing services unless explicitly approved?
Are risk based authentication policies such as geo based or device based policies reviewed and tuned on a regular basis?
Are external and internal APIs that perform user specific actions protected by strong authentication mechanisms?
Do APIs distinguish between machine to machine authentication and end user based authentication with appropriate controls for each?
Are API keys or tokens associated with user or service identities generated and rotated in line with a defined standard?
Are machine to machine authentication methods such as mutual TLS or signed tokens used instead of static passwords where possible?
Are failed API authentication attempts logged with sufficient detail and monitored for unusual patterns?
Are separate administrative accounts used for administrative activities rather than using standard user accounts?
Are administrative logins restricted to hardened admin interfaces such as jump hosts VPN or dedicated management networks?
Do you maintain emergency break glass administrative accounts with stronger authentication and strict access procedures?
Are credentials for privileged and emergency accounts stored and accessed through a controlled mechanism such as a password vault?
Are administrative authentication activities such as logins privilege elevation and session starts recorded and reviewed?
Are authentication logs from critical systems centralized to a logging or SIEM platform?
Do you have defined alerting rules for suspicious authentication related events such as multiple failures or unusual geolocation access?
Is there a documented process to investigate and respond to authentication related alerts and anomalies?
Do you correlate authentication events with other security telemetry such as endpoint or network logs to detect complex attacks?
Are authentication and access logs retained for a period that meets business legal and regulatory requirements?
Do you maintain a documented authentication standard that references relevant regulations and security frameworks?
Are authentication controls and configurations periodically assessed as part of internal or external security audits?
Are authentication requirements for third party and customer facing systems defined in contracts or security requirements documents?
Are authentication mechanisms and configurations included within regular penetration testing or red team exercises?
Are lessons learned from authentication related incidents used to update authentication policies standards and technical controls?
Is Role Based Access Control RBAC implemented for managing user access across systems?
Are roles formally defined and documented based on business functions?
Are users assigned roles rather than individual permissions wherever feasible?
Are role definitions reviewed periodically to ensure relevance and necessity?
Are role changes subject to formal change approval processes?
Are privileged roles clearly separated from standard user roles?
Are role assignments logged and auditable?
Are duplicate or overlapping roles periodically rationalized?
Are role conflicts identified during role design?
Are role definitions aligned with HR job profiles?
Are generic roles restricted and monitored?
Are application owners involved in role definition?
Are role catalogs centrally maintained?
Are obsolete roles removed promptly?
Are role assignment approvals recorded?

Are users granted only the minimum level of access required to perform their job functions?
Are access rights reviewed during role changes to remove unnecessary privileges?

Are privileged permissions granted only on a need basis?

Are unused elevated privileges revoked automatically after expiry?

Are SoD violations reviewed as compliance metrics?

Is there segregation between requester and approver?
Are access requests tracked until completion?
